Schedule.title: Schedule
Schedule.description: Represents a schedule for a church service or event.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Schedule entity.

date.description: Date and time of the scheduled service or event.

description.description: A brief description of the schedule.

memberIds.description: References to Members participating in the schedule. (Relationship: Schedule 1:N Member)

songIds.description: References to Songs included in the schedule. (Relationship: Schedule 1:N Song)

Song.title: Song
Song.description: Represents a song in the music library.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Song entity.

capo.description: Capo of the song, if available.

Member.title: Member
Member.description: Represents a member of the church.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Member entity.

contactNumber.description: Contact phone number of the member.

role.description: Role of the member (e.g., Singer, Musician, Sound Engineer).

Playlist.title: Playlist
Playlist.description: Represents a playlist of songs for a specific purpose (e.g., upcoming service).

id.description: Unique identifier for the Playlist entity.

description.description: Description of the playlist (e.g., purpose, occasion).

songIds.description: References to Songs included in the playlist. (Relationship: Playlist 1:N Song)

definition.description: Stores song data.  No specific ownership, so top-level collection.  All songs are generally accessible.
Stores member data. No specific ownership, so top-level collection. All members are generally accessible.
Stores schedule data. Includes denormalized 'members' map for authorization independence. The 'members' map contains user IDs with their corresponding roles (e.g., 'admin', 'participant').
Stores playlists created by users. Path-based ownership ensures only the user can access their own playlists.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to reflect the application's core features: Schedule View, Music Library, Member Directory, and Playlist Management. The structure prioritizes authorization independence and predictable security rules. User-owned data is structured under `/users/{userId}`. Collaborative data, such as schedules, uses membership maps for access control. The `members` map on the Schedule document denormalizes access control, enabling atomic operations and avoiding `get()` calls in security rules. This design also ensures that listing schedules is secure, as the rules do not act as filters (QAPs). Segregation is achieved by placing user-specific data (like playlists) under their respective user IDs, ensuring that different collections have distinct security postures. Songs are stored in a top-level collection to simplify access and management, given that they are not directly user-owned.
